title: Exploring Earth and Environmental Sciences
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC1000.
description: (UGEB1870 is double-coded with EESC1001.) The course provides an interdisciplinary study of the Earth Systems, including natural phenomena in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere. The mechanism of these systems, associated dynamics and anthropogenic impacts will be introduced and discussed. The course also serves as a platform to understand and critically assess global environmental change, natural hazards, biodiversity loss, and the water-energy-food nexus, and explore potential technological and policy solutions to these problems. These objectives align strongly with the understanding and pursuit of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, especially SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life Below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land. In addition to attending lectures, students will visit the Jockey Club Museum of Climate Change where it displays the way scientists examine past and current climate and the factors leading to current global temperature change. A geological field excursion will be another highlight of the course to demonstrate the scientific concepts applied to reveal Earth’s tectonic history, evolution and interaction among various spheres. With diverse scientific topics in Earth’s systems, the course shows students how each Earth’s system is interlocking with other spheres and, hence raise the awareness in the importance of sustainability.
outcome: Describe and explain how the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere interact and how feedback mechanisms operate among the Earth systems.  Develop an interdisciplinary approach for investigating Earth system dynamics.   Discuss the anthropogenic influences, as well as scientific and technical challenges related to global environmental changes, natural hazards, and the food-water-energy nexus critically.  Recognize the complexity of linkages between environmental pressures and human responses related to contemporary sustainable development challenges, contributing to the understanding and pursuit of SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land.  Communicate effectively about Earth system and environmental issues in an appropriate science format (i.e. scientific poster and QnA) through working independently and collaboratively.
syllabus: Lectures: To provide students basic concepts of different spheres, background information about present environmental phenomena and scientific approaches to study the Earth system  Tutorial: To guide students critically think about Earth system and related issues to our environment.  Visit: To show students how professional field works to understand our Earth  Field trip: To facilitate students observe the environment and interpret and discuss related environmental problems   Note: Students are expected to attend all lectures, and participate in all tutorials, the visit and the field trip. Meeting with academic advisors can be arranged upon request.     Course Syllabus (English) (Tentative)  The course content will be divided into three parts:     Part I: Geosphere and Cryosphere (Week 1-5)  This component focuses on studying the solid Earth using gravity, electromagnetic and seismic methods. Students will be introduced to the solid physical foundations of the solid Earth, as well as an overview of the structure and composition of the Earth, its materials and constituents, dynamics of its internal and external processes.     Part II: Atmosphere and Climate (Week 7-9)  This compenent covers an integrated introduction to the climate system and the dynamics and chemistry of the atmosphere. Students will learn to explain the history, current state and future projection of weather and climate, natural hazards, and global climate change in the context of natural variability and anthropogenic influence.     Part III: Ecosystem Interactions (Week 10-12)  This compenent covers the interactions of the terrestrial and marine biosphere with the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere. title: Introductory Practical Course in Earth and Environmental Sciences
description: The Introductory Practical Course in Earth and Environmental Sciences is a project-based learning experience designed to introduce freshmen to Earth and Environmental Sciences through direct field observation and hands-on project work. This course will be led by 3 instructors in Geology and Geophysics, Atmospheric Sciences and Environmental Sciences. By exploring the geology beneath our feet, the atmospheric currents above us, and the environmental issues that surround us, students will gain a holistic understanding of our planet.
outcome: 1. Introduction to Hong Kong Geology: Able to read the basic information from a geological map Gain a brief understanding in major rock types in Hong Kong  Understanding the geological history of Hong Kong Able to correlate the map information, outcrop properties and the landscape 2. Atmospheric Science - Earth’s Rotation and Weather: Describe the basic principles of Earth's rotation and the Coriolis effect and their influence on global weather patterns. Evaluate the impact of the Coriolis effect on weather systems, including the rotation of tropical cyclones, using meteorological data. Design and conduct laboratory experiments to apply theoretical knowledge of atmospheric science to simulate and analyze real-world weather phenomena. 3. Environmental Science - Water Quality: Summarize the key indicators of water quality and discuss their implications for ecosystem health and human well-being. Design and perform experiments to collect and assess water samples, measuring parameters such as pH, turbidity, and pollutants to determine water quality. Assess the sources and consequences of water pollution and propose viable solutions for improving water quality based on scientific evidence.
syllabus: Introduction to Hong Kong Geology: This field study takes students to a geologically interesting field area in Hong Kong, providing an outdoor classroom to understand geological processes. Students will learn practical field skills in identifying the rocks, reading geological maps, and understanding how the Earth’s processes shape the landscape.  Atmospheric Science - Earth’s Rotation and Weather: This part is designed to introduce students to the fundamental concepts of Earth's rotation and the Coriolis effect, and their impact on our weather such as the rotation of tropical cyclones. Through a combination of theoretical lectures and laboratory experiments, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of these phenomena.   Environmental Science - Water Quality: This practical study immerses students in the field of environmental science with a focus on water quality. Students will collect and analyze water samples from various sources, testing for parameters like pH, turbidity, and presence of pollutants. This project will underscore the importance of clean, healthy water for ecosystems and human societies, illustrating environmental challenges and potential solutions.

title: Solid Earth Dynamics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC2010.
description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the solid earth system stressing the geological, chemical, physical, and biological interactions among the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical concepts to explain the history and behaviour of the solid earth system. Geophysical and geochemical techniques for probing the interior of the earth are reviewed. Plate tectonics is introduced as a unifying theme to understand geodynamic processes. The course includes discussions of topics that are relevant to society, resources and sustainability, such as the physical and chemical basis of natural hazards (earthquakes, tsunami, landslides) and their mitigation, and the impact of geological processes on the global environment.
outcome: This course will contribute to the understanding of the dynamics of the solid Earth system, specifically the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere, as well as their interaction. The students should be able to: 1) describe and use the scientific process, explain how theories are built upon earth system observations, and how both are tested and revised; 2) explain how fundamental physical, chemical, and biological principles govern specific earth system processes; 3) participate knowledgeably and intelligently in discussions of public policy related to earth system science, particularly with respect to natural hazards, resources, environment and sustainable development; 4) work effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

title: Intermediate Earth and Environmental Field Study II
requirements: Pre-requisite: (EESC2010 or ESSC2010) and passed a Quiz, or with course coordinator's approval.
description: EESC2129 is designed to provide students with fundamental geological field techniques and the application of geological and environmental concepts specific to the region of Hong Kong. The course aims to deepen students' understanding of the local geology, including its formation processes, tectonic history, and its relationship with the environment. By the end of the course, students will have acquired a solid background in local geology and geomorphology. The course emphasizes hands-on training and practical skills development. Students will learn essential geological field techniques, including map reading, gathering geological data, making field observations, and jotting geological field notes. They will also develop critical thinking skills through the analysis and interpretation of geological data. Additionally, the course includes training in life-saving skills to ensure students' safety during fieldwork. EESC2129 consists of a 10-day local field study and five pre-trip lectures. The field study provides an immersive experience where students will directly apply the knowledge and techniques learned in the classroom to real geological settings in Hong Kong. The pre-trip lectures serve as a preparatory phase, covering relevant theoretical concepts, field methodologies, and safety protocols. Following the field study, two post-trip discussions will provide an opportunity for students to share their findings, and engage in further analysis and interpretation. Successful completion of EESC2129 requires continuous teamwork and independent assignments. Students will be expected to collaborate with their peers during fieldwork, share responsibilities, and contribute to group discussions. Additionally, independent assignments will be assigned to reinforce students' understanding of the course material and encourage individual exploration of specific geological topics.Note: This course may involve physical activities and fieldwork in outdoor environments. Students are advised to comply with safety guidelines, follow instructions from instructors, and maintain appropriate fitness levels to ensure a safe and enriching learning experience.

description: This is a foundation course designed to equip students with a proper understanding of the fundamental aspects of environmental chemistry. title: Elementary Methods for Earth and Environmental Sciences
requirements: Pre-requisite: (MATH1520 or MATH1010) or permission of instructor.
description: The course provides a survey of elementary analytical quantitative and qualitative methods commonly used in earth and environmental sciences, with applications in geophysics, geophysical/environmental fluid dynamics, as well as related aspects in thermodynamics and wave physics. Teaching aided by numerical programming is adopted and emphasized, in addition to analytical understanding of these methods. Typical examples include heat conduction on earth surface, seismic and ocean waves, air pollution, geodynamics, and atmospheric dynamics.
outcome: An understanding of elementary quantitative methods used in earth and environmental sciences. Appreciation of how physical principles in earth and environmental sciences are formulated quantitatively,  Knowledge of the application of elementary methods in solving problems in earth and environmental sciences.
syllabus: Basic solid Mechanics: Equation of motions of solid, Hooke’s law, plane strain and plane stress problems, Airy stress function (biharmonic equations), bending of beam and plates (nonhomogeneous biharmonic equation), Solution method of elasticity, Helmholtz decomposition theorem for displacement field, use of gradient, divergence and curl in formulating Lame strain potential and Love’s potential.  Geodynamics: Heat conduction in earth, Fourier law of heat conduction, error functions, instantaneous cooling of the half-space, age of the earth; lithospheric bending and folding.    Seismicity: single degree of oscillator, response spectrum, Helmholtz decomposition for velocity vectors, use of gradient, divergence and curl in formulating compression and shear wave equations. Rayleigh wave as surface wave; 2-D waves versus 3-D waves; Analysis of seismic signals using Fourier transforms, physical meaning of phase shift, physical meaning of Fourier transform magnitude. Basic fluid Mechanics: Circulation and vorticity, Helmholtz theorem, Kelvin circulation theorem and their implications, conservation of mass, derivation of Navier-Stokes equation, stream function for potential flow theory; Geophysical flows: Coriolis force as function of latitude, geophysical scaling, Rossby number, Ekman number, and Reynold’s number; turbulent diffusion in fluids and atmosphere, Duhamel integral for time varying boundary condition, Taylor’s point source solution (1-D, 2-D and 3-D cases), pollutant diffusion in river, ocean, and atmosphere; Ogata-Banks solution; Gaussian plume model for smoke diffusion; Kelvin-Helmholtz instability. Atmospheric flows: vortex models, maximum wind speed in tornadoes, maximum wind speed in typhoons, eyewall dynamics, buoyance instability in atmosphere; Taylor-Proudman theorem; radiative transfer equation (integro-differentiation equation) and climate change, use of radiative transfer model in remote sensing data assimilation and numerical weather forecast.   Ocean waves: Perturbation theory and Stokes wave theory, stream functions, Airy’s wave theory, shallow water and deep- water limits, dispersion relation, shallow water equation, conical theory for ocean waves, solitary wave or solitons. storm surges (inverse barometer effect, moving depression effect, wind-induced surge).

title: Structural Geology

description: This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the processes and products of rock deformation in three dimensions, ranging from micro- (micron) to macro- (kilometer) scales. It discusses geometries and mechanism of faults, folds, structural features of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks, and superposed deformations and introduces regional deformational history and tectonics. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise and demonstrations as well as field trips to local or overseas outcrops.

Labs use geological maps, computers, stereonets, and physical analogs to illustrate these concepts. Students are encouraged to lead discussion of leading geological topics spread throughout the semester, each of which integrates recent class topics with large-scale active tectonics. Field trips in the second half of the semester encourage small-group discussion of observations and interpretations of deformational history of the field working area. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. title: Global Environmental Change
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC3800.
description: This course includes the science behind the global warming issue, how the public views the issue and the critical thinking needed to analyze the evidence seen in the media/articles from the point of view of scientists. The world energy use, which is considered to be the cause of global warming, and the impacts are discussed in the course. In this course, students will learn about the radiation budgets/balance in the atmosphere, possible climate forcings that can upset the energy balance, how the earth’s global average temperature is measured, why global warming is described as “the biggest hoax” in human history, observations from the ocean and cryosphere and popular environmental issues/arguments discussed in the mainstream media. Newest observations from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report are included throughout the course.This course actively incorporates elements of innovation, design, global citizenship and social enterprisingness by asking the students to think innovatively but critically about possible solutions to adapt to and combat climate change and the global energy/health crisis. Different options including their pros and cons are actively discussed in class. Students are encouraged to think creatively about the problem from different angles, e.g., by standing in the shoes of climate skeptics – evaluating their “data”, how they present them, the arguments put forth by them – in order to develop a strategic approach to best communicate the issues to a variety of stakeholders. Project assignments will allow students to focus on one particular environmental issue in other part of the world, attempting to address the issue in the very different geographical, cultural, economic and political contexts from that of the students. Example projects can be “How to use geoengineering to combat climate change?”, “How can Sub-Saharan Africa secure its future food supply under the threat of climate change?”, etc. In the course, students will define and understand the problem. They shall form groups and discuss their own point of views and search information on the evidence of the corresponding arguments. They will present their ideas in class and write a self-reflection report. Each of the group will have to make an “infographic”- a layout of science knowledge learnt in the project that is easy enough for the public to understand but at the same time informative. Good infographics will be used in our OpenDay.
outcome: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to gain understanding of basic climate science behind the global warming issue, including how Earth’s global temperature has been measured by scientists and how the global average temperature is calculated study observations from different components of Earth besides the atmosphere, such as ocean and cryosphere observations, and how these components are affected by the human activities study how the scientific problem is presented and perceived in the society and learn how to use one’s scientific knowledge to identify possible solutionsThe active incorporation of elements of innovation and design in the course is critical in allowing the students to develop a keen scientific mindset and logic flow to understand the complexity of the climate change and energy issues (Learning Outcome #1), and to dissect the reasons behind contradictory arguments in a society (Learning Outcome #3). Critical evaluation of the arguments from both sides (climate alarmists vs. skeptics) will ultimately allow them to develop their own stance in the issue, and think critically about the ways to move the world forward towards sustainability (Learning Outcome #3). The incorporation of global citizenship and social enterprisingness is also crucial for students to develop a keen awareness of how environmental issues affect people in a huge variety of geographical and cultural contexts (Learning Outcome #2), and think critically about what kinds of solutions best fit a certain region (Learning Outcome #3).

description: Understanding Earth processes and environmental changes over geological time requires the experience and skills gained from fieldwork. EESC4119 is an advanced-level course of the Earth and Environmental Sciences Programme. It covers important aspects of field geology, including petrology, structural geology, tectonics, geophysics, and surficial processes. The principal goal of this course is to train students to recognize different lithological units and their spatial relationship in three dimensions, and to understand the related tectonic environment and formation mechanisms. Class lectures introduce basic skills of reading and interpreting geological maps, using geological equipment (i.e., compass-clinometer, GPS receiver), and producing field notes and reports. Field projects include field observation and description, techniques for field data acquisition and analysis, sample collection, and geological map compilation. Field projects also focus on surficial processes, which occur over relatively short geological timescales but play important roles in environment and ecology. The field location, whether in mainland China or overseas, may change from year to year.

title: Petrology
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4120. Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010.
description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth and Environmental Sciences because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).
outcome: Students are expected to gain the following abilities: Gain the skills to identify different rock types (igneous and metamorphic basically). Good knowledge of typical mineral assemblages of different rocks. Use optical polarizing microscope to distinguish: (1) different minerals based on their optical properties, (2) typical igneous and metamorphic micro-textures and structures, (3) featured mineral assemblages corresponding to different P-T conditions. Understand phase equilibrium and phase rule and their applications in understanding the rock forming process. Understand different metamorphic facies and their significance of variable tectonic settings. Use petrologic concepts and theories to address topics of societal interests, including natural hazards, natural resources, and human health issues. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

title: Geomorphology
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4130. Pre-requisite: EESC3100 or ESSC3100.
description: This course is an important part of the core Earth and Environmental Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the main concepts in geomorphology with emphasis on understanding the coupling of environments, processes and materials that leads to landform development. Understanding the underlying geological principles of rocks, minerals, structural deformation and geological time are important background knowledge to be enhanced by the study of geomorphology.It discusses the qualitative and quantitative techniques for investigation and research in the field, laboratory, and computer simulation. The application of geomorphology for public safety, engineering problems and development of sustainable solutions will be emphasized. Examples from theory and practice of geomorphology in Hong Kong will be introduced. Practical understanding and skills will be gained from lab exercises and field trips in Hong Kong.Students are suggested to be equipped with basic knowledge of rocks and minerals, structural geology and geological time scale.
outcome: Students are expected to gain the following abilities: Understand the relationships between materials, processes and landforms; Use concepts of solid and fluid mechanics to interpret the formation of landforms; Use graphical tools to compile and interpret field and laboratory data; Integrate topics in mineralogy, petrology, structural geology, plate tectonics, climate sciences, biogeosciences, hydrology, remote sensing and geotechnical engineering through survey of scientific literature, case studies, books and textbooks; and Make primary observations in the field and using them to construct and test hypotheses. Lectures focus on physical and chemical aspects of landform evolution and understanding spatial patterns in landscapes and how humans affect and are impacted by Earth surface processes. Labs use the geological maps, terrain classification maps, aerial photography interpretation, societal consequence assessment, and physical models to illustrate these concepts.Students are encouraged to ask, follow-up research and lead discussion of questions regarding lecture topics throughout the semester. Field trips in the second half of the semester encourage small-group discussion of observations and interpretations of landscape evolution and human impacts in mountainous and coastal terrains.The students will develop the ability:1)to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles;2)to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently;3)to work effectively in a team, and 4)to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students will also be challenged to manage a large amount of reading in short periods of time and to think of their role as a citizen and in society.

requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4140. Pre-requisite: (EESC3120 or ESSC3120) or ESSC3010.
description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of elastic wave propagation and physics of earthquake. title: Volcanoes
description: On any given day, ~20 subaerial volcanoes worldwide are erupting. Even more submarine volcanoes are probably erupting without being detected. Volcanic eruptions can have devastating economic and social consequences, but are also the fundamental force that builds the majority of our planet’s surface. Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. This course will explore the various techniques used to study volcanoes’ underlying structure as well as their precursory and eruptive activity.
outcome: At the completion of this course, the students will understand fundamental concepts related to volcanic systems as well as the various techniques used to monitor and study volcanoes. The students will also be trained to read scientific literature, learn new knowledge from them, and synthesize with existing knowledge. Finally, students will learn how to present scientific information in a clear, succinct, and logical manner in both oral and written form as well as in scientific discourse/debate.

description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of marine geology and geophysics. Marine geology is distinct from that of continent and is the important foundation to launch Plate Tectonics, the modern unified theory of the Earth. In this course, major components of marine geological settings such as mid-ocean ridges, transform faults, subduction zones, oceanic lithosphere, and etc. will be introduced and discussed in details. Methods of geophysical survey will also be introduced. Field experiments of scientific instruments such as Ocean Bottom Seismometers, marine magnetometer and gravimeter will be conducted. A geological field trip will also be included. This course will be jointly offered with Ocean College, Zhejiang University, as an initiative to develop ocean sciences at CUHK.

Geodynamics is going to answer those questions through observations and models of the large-scale behaviors of the solid Earth. The goal of the course is to develop a thorough understanding of physical processes, such as lithospheric deformation, heat transfer, and mantle flow. title: Land-Atmosphere Interactions and Boundary-Layer Meteorology
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4210. Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) or (EESC3200 or ESSC3200) or permission of instructor.
description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological processes governing the exchange of energy, momentum, water and other chemical materials between the atmosphere and land surface, including a formal introduction into boundary-layer meteorology. Applications to weather phenomena, air pollution, forestry, agriculture and ecosystem management will be emphasized throughout.

description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. title: Cloud Dynamics
requirements: Pre-requisite: EESC2020 or ESSC2020.
description: This course presents an introduction to clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing some of the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing shall be presented. These shall then feedback onto our beginning description of clouds on the global climatological level. Student taking this course are expected to have taken EESC2020 or ESSC2020.

They shall understand the processes determining all the types of clouds in our atmosphere, over a wide range of spatial scales from microns to thousands of kilometers. They shall appreciate the importance of cloud to Earth’s climate. There may also be opportunities (e.g. outdoor cloud observations, computer visualization of clouds) where student can practice working effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

description: This course introduces the principles and applications of various chemical and physiochemical processes applicable for treatment and control of air and water pollution. title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth and Environmental Sciences
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESSC4510. Pre-requisite: (STAT1011 or 1012), and ((EESC2030 or ESSC2030) or PHYS2061).
description: This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth and environmental sciences. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data.Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.
outcome: Students will become knowledgeable about the acquisition, pre-processing and analysis of geophysical and environmental data, including remote sensing, in situ observation and model data. Students will acquire knowledge on techniques for data processing, including visualization methods and statistical analysis, and on the applications of these data and tools to geophysical and environmental problems. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students can also acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

title: Practical Atmospheric Modeling
requirements: Pre-requisite: (EESC2020 or ESSC2020) and (MATH2550 or EESC2520 or PHYS2051) and (PHYS1001 or 1002 or 1111 or 1113), or permission of instructor.
description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
